title: 103_hr257
content: The Act may be cited as the "Health Care Crisis Policy Commission Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress finds that the cost of medical care is increasing, leading to financial difficulties for Americans. In 1988, millions lacked health insurance or were underinsured, creating high levels of uncompensated care. There is a significant need for basic medical services, especially as the population ages. Long-term health care insurance is inadequate, with the average cost of a year-long stay in a facility being $25,000. The medical care system for American veterans is inadequate, with high costs of medical care and a need for tort reform to reduce expenses. There is a shortage of essential services like prenatal and well-baby care, leading to excessive spending on end-of-life procedures instead of preventative measures. The current issues in healthcare include the need to improve federal income tax incentives for employer-paid group health insurance, regulate self-insured healthcare coverage for adequate protection, address concerns about Medicare solvency due to low payment rates for physicians, and tackle inadequate healthcare in rural areas leading to hospital closures. The "Health Care Crisis Policy Commission" is established by this Act to address current healthcare issues such as improving tax incentives for employer-paid health insurance, regulating self-insured coverage, addressing Medicare solvency concerns, and tackling inadequate healthcare in rural areas. The Commission will study the escalating costs of medical care and health insurance in the US, explore alternatives for uninsured individuals, evaluate private sector options for health insurance, review future demands on the healthcare system as the population ages, and assess long-term care costs. The Commission will also examine the costs of long-term care, evaluate the VA health care system, investigate medical malpractice liability reforms, review prenatal and well-baby care impact on healthcare costs, study tax incentives for employer-sponsored health insurance, and research self-insured businesses in healthcare coverage. The Commission will evaluate health insurance coverage regulations, rural healthcare delivery, Medicare financial stability, financing options for alternative healthcare systems, and incentives to improve healthcare efficiency and quality. The Commission will investigate areas related to the efficient and cost-effective delivery of health care, in addition to improving the quality of care. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 15 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader. Members must have knowledge in healthcare delivery, financing, economics, administration, or legal aspects. They must be selected from healthcare consumers, providers, employers, financial institutions, or related organizations. No more than 1 member per appointment may be a federal, state, or local government employee. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate majority leader. Members must have knowledge in healthcare delivery, financing, economics, administration, or legal aspects. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. No more than 3 members appointed under each paragraph may be of the same political party. Each member serves for the life of the Commission and receives basic pay according to the Executive Schedule. Members of the Commission who are federal employees or Members of Congress receive no additional pay, allowances, or benefits except for travel expenses. The Commission requires 8 members for a quorum, and the chairman and vice chairman are elected by the members. Meetings are held as needed. The Commission shall meet at the call of the chairman or a majority of its members. SEC. 6. STAFF; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The chairman of the Commission can hire staff in accordance with relevant laws. Staff will be paid based on established pay rates. The chairman can also procure services of experts and consultants. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, conduct sessions, and obtain official data with cooperation from federal agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and meetings must be open to the public as per federal regulations. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts, use the United States mails, and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment, detailing study findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. The Commission will dissolve 10 days after submitting the final report. Any spending authority authorized by the Act is subject to appropriation Acts.
